source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_017_chunk5
evidence_span: A strain-limit approach has been developed for the design of coldworked Zircaloy-2 pressure tubes. On the present evidence a 2 percent creep limit is recommended.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_017_chunk5
evidence_span: An expression has been developed for predicting the creep strain of cold-worked Zircaloy-2 pressure tubes in terms of flux, temperature, and stress.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_017_chunk5
evidence_span: Under the service conditions of stress, temperature, and flux, the pressure tubes of an SGHW reactor will creep 2 percent in 30 yr at 75 percent load factor.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_017_chunk5
evidence_span: Torsion tests were performed as part of a study of the effects of texture on the biaxial plastic properties of Zircaloy tubing.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_017_chunk5
evidence_span: The torsion yield strengths varied widely from lot to lot of tubing and, in every instance, were higher than those predicted by conventional failure theories.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_017_chunk5
evidence_span: Variation in yield strength is ascribed to the presence or absence of texture-strengthening in the plane acted upon by the torsion stresses.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_017_chunk5
evidence_span: The physical and mechanical properties of zirconium alloys are highly anisotropic because of the crystallographic preferred orientation (texture) developed during fabrication.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_017_chunk5
evidence_span: the fuel-rod cladding thickness necessary to contain the internal pressure of the fission gases and withstand the external primary system pressure in a light-water reactor may vary by 50 percent.
